extendedIngredients.name: caramelized onions
extendedIngredients.originalString: When the onions are fully caramelized, add the curry powder and saute briefly until very fragrant.

extendedIngredients.name: chicken
extendedIngredients.originalString: Clean any large bits of fat or tendon from the chicken and cut into large chunks. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon of pepper and mix to distribute evenly.
metaInformation: with 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon of pepper and mix to distribute evenly.

extendedIngredients.name: garlic oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: Add the grated garlic and ginger and fry in the oil until it's not sizzling as much and it reaches a rich caramel brown color.

extendedIngredients.name: low-salt chicken broth
extendedIngredients.originalString: Turn down the heat to medium-low and transfer the chicken to a bowl using tongs, making sure to leave as much oil in the pan as possible.

extendedIngredients.name: onions
extendedIngredients.originalString: Add the onions, and stir to coat with oil. Cover with a lid and let the onions steam until translucent and limp (about 10-15 minutes).
metaInformation: with oil. cover with a lid and let the onions steam until translucent and limp ( 10-15 minutes).

extendedIngredients.name: peas
extendedIngredients.originalString: Finish the curry by stirring in the roux and green peas and bringing to a boil to thicken the sauce.

extendedIngredients.name: potatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: When the potatoes are tender, taste and adjust salt to taste. If you like your curry sweeter, you can add some honey.

extendedIngredients.name: potatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: Add the potatoes, cover and simmer until the carrots and potatoes are very tender (another 15-20 minutes).

extendedIngredients.name: ready-to-serve Asian fried rice
extendedIngredients.originalString: Serve with hot rice, or on top of a bowl of udon.
metaInformation: with hot rice, or on top of a bowl of udon.

extendedIngredients.name: in the meantime
extendedIngredients.originalString: In the meantime, make the roux by adding the butter and flour to a small saucepan over medium heat. Use a spatula to stir constantly until the bubbling subsides and the roux is a light brown color.

winePairing.pairingText: Asian works really well with Riesling, Gewurztraminer, and Chenin Blanc. The best wine for Asian food depends on the cuisine and dish - of course - but these acidic whites pair with a number of traditional meals, spicy or not. The Poet's Leap Riesling with a 4 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 20 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Poet's Leap Riesling
productMatches.description: Key lime and fresh citrus peel aromas give way to vivid layers of white peach and stone fruit flavors accented by a pleasant touch of minerality. Delicious natural acidity and a hint of residual sugar provide a balanced, vibrant mouth-feel and lengthy finish.
